title: A Case of Chronic Low Back Pain in a Sedentary Office Worker
clinical_history: Meet John, a 42-year-old office worker who has been experiencing chronic low back pain for the past 6 months. He reports that the pain started gradually, with no specific incident or trauma. John spends most of his day sitting at a desk, working on a computer, and has a sedentary lifestyle. He has tried various treatments, including over-the-counter pain medications and physical therapy, but the pain persists.

nprs.affected_area: lower back, specifically the lumbar region

aggrevating_factors: prolonged sitting, standing, bending, lifting heavy objects, and twisting
picture: a diagram of the lumbar spine highlighting the affected area
easing_factors: rest, heat application, and gentle stretching
past_history: John has a history of intermittent back pain, which he attributes to his previous job as a manual laborer. He has not had any significant injuries or surgeries in the past 5 years.
medical_history: John has hypertension and high cholesterol, which are managed through medication and lifestyle modifications.
medications: acetaminophen 1000mg every 4-6 hours as needed for pain
personal_history: John is married with two children and works as an accountant in a large firm. He reports feeling stressed and overwhelmed at work, which he believes contributes to his back pain.
imaging: MRI of the lumbar spine shows mild degenerative changes at L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels, with no significant herniation or stenosis.
